title: Mr. Johnson's Battle with Persistent Hip Pain
clinical_history: Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old retired civil engineer who arrived at the clinic with complaints of persistent right hip pain. The pain has gradually worsened over the past six months and is especially disruptive in the mornings and after prolonged inactivity. He describes the pain as a deep, aching sensation that occasionally radiates down the anteromedial thigh. He experiences difficulty climbing stairs and getting up from a sitting position, often requiring support from the armrests or nearby furniture.
aggrevating_factors: prolonged sitting, walking for more than 15 minutes, climbing stairs, getting in and out of cars.
picture: [insert image of a person highlighting the right hip and groin areas]
easing_factors: rest, applying a heating pad, taking frequent sitting breaks when walking.
past_history: previous knee arthroscopy 4 years ago due to a meniscus tear. No prior hip issues.
medical_history: diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 7 years ago, hypertension for the last decade â€“ both are under control with medication.
medications: Metformin 500mg, Lisinopril 10mg daily, Ibuprofen 400mg as needed for pain.
personal_history: divorced, lives alone. Has two adult children who visit on weekends. Enjoys reading and gardening but has reduced his gardening activities due to the hip pain.
imaging: X-Ray showed mild osteoarthritic changes in the right hip, with narrowing of the joint space.
